instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2159: What is A2159? A2159 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2019 with EMC 3301, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01598..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.U6903: What is U6903? This chip is responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H in 2016-2018 model Macbook logic boards.
definitions.820-01598: What is 820-01598? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR: What is PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR? This is the input that comes from the charger..
definitions.ISL9240: What is ISL9240? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2018 through 2020.

threads.title: Macbook Air 5V 0.340A
threads.message:
Hello, I will start this by saying I am VERY new to logic board repair, I know basics and learn best by doing but have found this difficult as I can't find my exact problem and just chunks of it which makes things hard to track for me. 

It's a Macbook Air 2019 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>.  

It was apperantly used for 3 months then randomly stopped, I was asked to repair it a year or so later as Apple wanted to charge too much. 

It started off with 5v 0amps, I tracked down a problem with <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, <CHIP>U9080</CHIP> and <CHIP>U6903</CHIP>. When I replaced these I started getting 5v and 0.340A. I can't seem to get any further than this and have gotten a bit confused in the process, I can't remeber exactly what lead me to <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> as this was about a month ago while waiting for new chips but <CHIP>U9080</CHIP> was shorting to ground. 

Voltages:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 5.02V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>: 0.00V 
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL>: 0.00V

No short to ground that I can find anywhere, no visible damage, no liquid damage. 

Any help is massivly appriciated.

threads.title: Macbook Air 5V 0.340A
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

"<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 5.02V"
Are you sure about this?
Isn't <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> instead?
We need accurate information...

Post diode mode to ground readings on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> (F7000), L6900 and L9080.

threads.title: Macbook Air 5V 0.340A
threads.message:
Hi, 

Yes I get a specific and constant 5.02v on every point for <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> according to open board , specifically: F7000, <RESISTOR>R6700</RESISTOR>, F84000, CD770, CD771.

<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> gives 5V at F3000, CD720, <RESISTOR>R7015</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7071</RESISTOR>. 

For the resistance multimeter set at 2k ohms: 

L6900: .381 & .389 
L9080: .411 & .412
F7000: .466


What I have now noticed just by chance is that <TRANSISTOR>Q7040</TRANSISTOR> (SIZ342DT) is producing a small amount of heat, not sure if this is a sign of a issue or just because the board was plugged in.

threads.title: Macbook Air 5V 0.340A
threads.message:
Check for short between <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> and F7000.
You should chabge <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>/40 anyway.

BTW, I said "diode mode", not 2K, or other ohm scale...

threads.title: Macbook Air 5V 0.340A
threads.message:
Sorry, readings were all OL diode mode so thought the actual readings would be mroe helpful. 

So yes, I think there is a short? This is where I'm still new to everything and to what to do next, If i put one probe on F7000 G3H and one on <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> pin 2, <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL> I get a short (a beep).

threads.title: Macbook Air 5V 0.340A
threads.message:
Beep is not equal short!
Multimeters beep until 0.050-0.075 (diode mode), depending by model.
However, such low value is not good at all between <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
I hope you did the test without power applied on the board.

Now change <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>/40.

"readings were all OL diode mode"
With red probe connected on ground y black on test point???
[URL unfurl="true"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/how-to-collection.60974/[/URL]

threads.title: Macbook Air 5V 0.340A
threads.message:
Just rechecked everything to be sure, power supply not connected at all. 

Diode mode readings are all "1  .  " with red probe on a screw hole and black probe on point. 

It will be next week sometime before I can change <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> & 40 because I have to order the components in.

threads.title: Macbook Air 5V 0.340A
threads.message: I have changed <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> & 40 and no change except there is now 1. instead of a beep between F7000 & <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> now has 0.15v.

threads.title: Macbook Air 5V 0.340A
threads.message:
Check solders, traces and components related with <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>/40.
Also try another <CHIP>ISL9240</CHIP>.
